item.title: Reticulate Explained With Abalones
item.description: library(reticulate) Sys.setenv(Reticulate_Python = "C:/Users/shigg/AppData/Local/r-miniconda/envs/r-reticulate/python.exe") use_python("C:/Users/shigg/AppData/Local/r-miniconda/envs/r-reticulate/python.exe") conda_create("r-reticulate") ## [1] "C:\\Users\\shigg\\AppData\\Local\\r-miniconda\\envs\\r-reticulate\\python.exe" use_condaenv("r-reticulate") py_install("pandas") ‘Reticulate’ is an R package that allows you to call python from R. Doing so will allow you to work with R and python interchangeably within RStudio’s R Markdown feature. import pandas as pd ab = pd.read_csv(r'\Users\shigg\OneDrive\Documents\College Notes\PyRe\Data sets\abalone_original.csv') ab = ab[['sex','rings']] print(ab) ## sex rings ## 0 M 15 ## 1 M 7 ## 2 F 9 ## 3 M 10 ## 4 I 7 ## .

item.title: Projects
item.description: Projects Here are some projects I have recently completed: Exploratory Data Analysis with Tidyverse Tools Modeling, Testing, and Classification Covid-19 in Texas

item.title: Project 1: Exploratory Data Analysis
item.description: Introduction The datasets I have chosen for this project are DMepi and pr, which are both found within the epi package in R. Both datasets contain variables related to the onset of diabetes in a Danish population. Pr is specialized towards diabetes prevalence in Denmark and contains variables such as age, sex, population size, and number of diabetes patients. DMepi contains more of the same as pr, however it differs in that it has variables related to mortality and person-years, with and without the diabetes condition.

item.title: Project 2: Modeling, Testing, and Predicting
item.description: Introduction library(tidyverse) ## -- Attaching packages --------------------------------------------------------- tidyverse 1.3.0 -- ## v ggplot2 3.2.1 v purrr 0.3.3 ## v tibble 2.1.3 v dplyr 0.8.3 ## v tidyr 1.0.0 v stringr 1.4.0 ## v readr 1.3.1 v forcats 0.5.0 ## -- Conflicts ------------------------------------------------------------ tidyverse_conflicts() -- ## x dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter() ## x dplyr::lag() masks stats::lag() liverd <- read.csv("https://github.com/zhamuelh/samprojects2/raw/master/Data%20sets/liverdrecords.csv") liverd <- liverd %>% rename(Liver_Disease = Dataset) %>% rename(Total_Proteins = Total_Protiens) %>% mutate(Liver_Disease = ifelse(Liver_Disease == "1", 1, 0)) %>% na.

item.title: SDS 323 Project
item.description: Abstract For this project, I wanted to look at Covid-19 cases over time for a few Texas counties and compare them through data visualization. I wanted to know which counties are experiencing a high number of cases and which counties are experiencing a low number of cases. Cases are ultimately dependent on the number of testing that’s done. What I found was that some counties are not on the same page in terms of cases reported.
